If you are arrested by ICE:  You have the right to remain silent – ICE can use anything you say against you in your immigration case  You have the right to speak with a lawyer  Don’t sign any documents before speaking to a lawyer #KnowYourRights! https://twitter.com/RepEspaillat/status/1142152508418220032 …

Una de las cosas más importantes que la isla tiene para ofrecer es su hospitalidad y una sonrisa amistosa. Mi familia y yo continuaremos nuestro viaje anual a la República Dominicana como parte de nuestra tradición familiar y en celebración de nuestra herencia.

Según el reciente informe publicado por el Departamento de Estado de los Estados Unidos, no ha habido un aumento en el número de muertes de turistas estadounidenses que visitan la isla. @StateDept https://abcnews.go.com/International/us-state-dept-uptick-deaths-americans-dominican-republic/story?id=63806929 …
Hablaré con los líderes de turismo y los funcionarios del gobierno para asegurar que estas muertes reciban investigaciones completas sobre las circunstancias de cada uno de estos casos.
Mi corazón y mis condolencias están con las familias de los turistas estadounidenses que murieron mientras visitaban la isla.

Mi familia y yo hemos viajado a la isla durante numerosos años y continuaremos viajando al país y seguiremos con nuestras tradiciones como familia para que mis hijos y mi nieto puedan conocer sus raíces y más sobre el país donde nací.
He recibido varias llamadas telefónicas luego de mi anuncio ayer de que viajaré a República Dominicana el 1 de julio. Estaré viajando a la República Dominicana como turista.

One of the most important things the island has to offer is its hospitality and friendly smile. My family and I will continue our annual travel to the #DominicanRepublic as part of our family tradition and in celebration of our heritage.

Based on the recent report released by the @StateDept, there has been no uptick in the number of deaths of American tourists visiting the island. https://abcnews.go.com/International/us-state-dept-uptick-deaths-americans-dominican-republic/story?id=63806929 …

My heart & condolences go out to the families of the American tourists who have died while visiting the island. I'll be speaking to tourism leaders & government officials to ensure these deaths receive full investigations surrounding the circumstances around each of these cases.

My family and I have traveled to the island for a number of years and will continue to travel to the country and continue our traditions as a family so that my children and my grandson can learn of their roots and more about the country of my birth.
I have received several phone calls following my announcement yesterday that I will be traveling to the #DominicanRepublic on July 1st. I am traveling to the Dominican Republic as a tourist.

On #WorldRefugeeDay, I'm proud to support bipartisan legislation introduced by @RepTedLieu @MarioDB @RepJoeNeguse @RepZoeLofgren to reaffirm U.S. commitment to protect refugees. Thank you @HouseForeign for marking up this important legislation today! pic.twitter.com/drffdexMDY

In 2018, the international community recorded 70.8 million displaced people, refugees & asylum seekers fleeing violence & persecution in every region of the world. On #WorldRefugeeDay, I join my colleagues to affirm our nation’s commitment to protect refugees.

Congress should send a strong message that the U.S - a country whose story has been written by those fleeing oppression and hardship – will not abandon the world’s most vulnerable populations. I’m proud to join my colleagues in recognizing today as #WorldRefugeeDay

The UN Refugee Agency estimates that half the world’s refugees are children – a reminder of how much work there still is to do. Today, no matter our race, religion, gender, or sexual orientation, we recommit ourselves to working to free modern-day slaves around the world and to honoring in our own time the efforts of those who fought so hard to steer our country truer to our highest ideals. #Juneteenth pic.twitter.com/ZCK1PU5p0v

#Fact: Texas slave owners weren't too eager to part with their slaves. When legally freed slaves tried to leave, many of them were beaten, lynched, or murdered. We cannot forget. #Juneteenth #Juneteenth2019 pic.twitter.com/clR6XnhV5i

#DidYouKnow that the June 19th announcement came more than two & a half years after Abraham Lincoln issued the Emancipation Proclamation? Although the 250,000 slaves in Texas were already free, none of them were aware of it, and no one was in a rush to inform them. #Juneteenth

On this #Juneteenth, let's remember to recommit ourselves to the work that remains undone. Let's remember that even in the darkest hours, there is cause to hope for tomorrow’s light. #TodayIsJuneteenth

#OnThisDay on June 19, 1865, General Gordon Granger rode into Galveston, Texas, and announced that slaves were now free. Since then, June 19th has been celebrated as #Juneteenth across the United States. #TodayIsJuneteenth pic.twitter.com/28sCsTbt7s

#Reparations and HR 40 is ultimately about respect and reconciliation—and the hope that one day, all Americans can walk together toward a more just future

Fact: #HR40 does not mandate financial payments of any kind and it does not prejudge the outcome of the commission’s work.  Instead, it sets forth a process by which a diverse group of experts and stakeholders can study the complex issues involved and make recommendations

With the rise and normalization of white supremacist expression during the Trump administration, #HR40 and the concept of restorative justice have gained more urgency and illustrates the need for a national reckoning.

We still live with racial disparities in access to education, health care, housing, insurance, employment and other social goods that are directly attributable to the damaging legacy of slavery and government-sponsored racial discrimination
Even long after slavery was abolished, segregation and subjugation of African Americans was a defining part of this nation’s policies that shaped its values and its institutions.  #HR40

American Slavery is our country’s original sin and its existence at the birth of our nation is a permanent scar on our country’s founding documents, and on the venerated authors of those documents, and it is a legacy that continued well into the last century.

#HR40 is intended to begin a national conversation about how to confront the brutal mistreatment of African-Americans during chattel slavery, Jim Crow segregation, and the enduring structural racism that remains endemic to our society today. https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2014/06/the-case-for-reparations/361631/ …
400 years ago, ships set sail from the west coast of Africa and in the process, began one of mankind’s most inhumane practices: human bondage and slavery.

We marked the 400th anniversary of the first enslaved Africans arriving at the colony of Jamestown, Virginia.  #HR40 gives us the opportunity to reflect on the shameful legacy of slavery and Jim Crow in this country, and to examine how we can best move forward as a nation.
American Slavery is our country’s original sin, and that’s why I support a path to Restorative Justice
#Reparations is a holistic inquiry to address the gaping wound in the soul of America. That’s why I’m proud to support HR40 pic.twitter.com/rp4P8PPRjA
I support a path to Restorative Justice. #HR40
